Archaeologists Say This 9,500-Year-Old Burial Is the Oldest Known Evidence of Intentional Cremation Discovered in Africa
Located in Malawi, the site could also be the world‚Äôs earliest example of an in situ cremation pyre for an adult, according to a new study
A large mound of ash containing burned bone fragments has been discovered in Malawi. The remains belonged to a Stone Age woman, and experts think the site could be the oldest known cremation pyre found in Africa, according to a study published this month in the journal Science Advances.
‚ÄúCremation is very rare among ancient and modern hunter-gatherers, at least partially because pyres require a huge amount of labor, time and fuel to transform a body into fragmented and calcined bone and ash,‚Äù says lead author Jessica Cerezo-Rom√°n, an anthropologist at the University of Oklahoma, in a statement.
The researchers found the ashes at Mount Hora in northern Malawi. Study co-author Jessica Thompson, an anthropologist at Yale University, tells NPR‚Äôs Nell Greenfieldboyce that hunter-gatherers camped, hunted, lit fires and buried their dead within the rocky shelters at the mountain‚Äôs base.
In the 1950s, researchers first discovered that a site known as Hora 1, located beneath a stone overhang at the base of the mountain, was once a hunter-gatherer burial ground. Thompson has been studying the site since 2016, and her research suggested that humans first inhabited Hora 1 about 21,000 years ago. They used the site to bury their dead between about 16,000 and 8,000 years ago, though these burials were complete skeletons.
As such, researchers were surprised when recent excavations revealed a layer of ash as large as a queen-size bed. The cremation burial contained the remains of one woman, though her skull was missing.
‚ÄúThere is something really unusual about either this person in life or this person in death,‚Äù co-author Elizabeth Sawchuk, the curator of human evolution at the Cleveland Museum of Natural History, tells NPR. ‚ÄúWhether something positive, whether something negative, we just don‚Äôt know, but that‚Äôs also what makes this discovery really spectacular.‚Äù
Using radiocarbon dating, the researchers determined the cremation occurred about 9,500 years ago. They then analyzed the burned bones using forensic and bioarchaeological techniques, write Cerezo-Rom√°n, Thompson and Sawchuk in the Conversation. Evidence suggests the remains likely belong to a middle-aged woman. She was just under five feet tall, though she appears to have been physically active before her death.
Microscopic incisions on the skeleton‚Äôs arms and legs indicate that some of the woman‚Äôs flesh may have been removed before or during the cremation. However, according to the Conversation, ‚ÄúPatterns of warping, cracks and discoloration caused by fire damage showed her body was burned with some flesh still on it.‚Äù The researchers think that large amounts of wood and grass were gathered for the fire, which they estimate would have reached at least 1,000 degrees Fahrenheit.
However, the archaeologists are still baffled by many details of the site. ‚ÄúWhat keeps me up at 2 a.m. is, where is her head?‚Äù Sawchuk tells NPR.
Because humans‚Äô dense skull bones usually preserve well in cremations, the researchers hypothesize that the woman‚Äôs head was removed, perhaps as part of a funerary ritual, per the Conversation. The woman‚Äôs bones were found in two clusters, suggesting her body was moved during the cremation.
‚ÄúThere is no evidence to suggest that they were doing any kind of violent act or cannibalism to the remains,‚Äù Cerezo-Rom√°n says to the Guardian‚Äôs Nicola Davis. Instead, as Sawchuk tells the publication, ‚Äúsome of the missing bones from the cremated woman may have been deliberately removed and taken as tokens for curation or reburial elsewhere.‚Äù
This discovery is also unique for its age, write the researchers. The world‚Äôs oldest known evidence of cremation is a roughly 40,000-year-old burial found at Lake Mungo in Australia. However, the earliest known in situ funeral pyre containing human remains is in Alaska, where a young child was buried around 11,500 years ago.
Quick fact: The cremation at Lake Mungo
Discovered in 1968, this roughly 40,000-year-old burial represents ‚Äúone of the earliest anatomically modern human remains discovered anywhere in the world,‚Äù according to the National Museum of Australia.
Before the new discovery, the earliest known evidence of burned human remains in Africa dated back around 7,500 years, and the continent‚Äôs oldest confirmed cremations are about 3,300 years old. According to a statement, the newly discovered site ‚Äúprovides the earliest evidence of intentional cremation in Africa and describes the world‚Äôs oldest known in situ cremation pyre containing the remains of an adult.‚Äù
The discovery also offers new insights into hunter-gatherer communities. The researchers estimate that humans used at least 66 pounds of deadwood and grass to cremate the woman at Hora 1, stoking the fire for hours or days. Additionally, radiocarbon dating of ash samples showed that this ‚Äúwas not the first fire at the Hora 1 site‚Äînor its last,‚Äù per the Conversation. ‚ÄúWhile there is no evidence that anyone else was cremated in the subsequent fires, the fact that people repeatedly returned to the spot for this purpose suggests its significance lived on in community memory.‚Äù
In hunter-gatherer communities, evidence of such attachment to land across generations is rare. The researchers hope that additional excavations in the area will help them determine why one woman was singled out and why the ritual was meaningful to her community.
‚ÄúThat it is such an early date, and that they would have been transient as hunter-gatherers makes it more amazing,‚Äù Joel Irish, an anthropologist and archaeologist at England‚Äôs Liverpool John Moores University who wasn‚Äôt involved in the study, tells the Guardian. ‚ÄúThey clearly had advanced belief systems and a high level of social complexity at this early date.‚Äù

Mummified Cheetahs Discovered in Caves Could Help Saudi Arabia Bring the Wild Cat Back to Its Historic Range
Researchers thought that just one subspecies of cheetah lived in Saudi Arabia long ago. But an unexpected discovery seems to broaden the gene pool
Asiatic cheetahs once roamed the land between the Arabian Peninsula and India, and they were thought to have been the only type of cheetah to have lived in Saudi Arabia. Today, the subspecies is critically endangered, with fewer than 70 individuals estimated to remain in the wild, only in Iran.
But a recent discovery could help boost their numbers. Over the past few years, researchers have uncovered mummies and skeletal remains of 61 cheetahs, which range from hundreds to thousands of years old, in caves in Saudi Arabia. Moreover, genetic analyses revealed that some of the ancient wild cats were more closely related to another living subspecies of cheetah than they were to the Asiatic variety.
The findings, published January 15 in the journal Communications Earth & Environment, point to new routes for rewilding efforts in the region.
‚ÄúThe key insight from our discovery is that more than one subspecies of cheetah inhabited Saudi Arabia,‚Äù study co-author Ahmed Al-Boug, a wildlife biologist and general director of Saudi Arabia‚Äôs National Center for Wildlife, tells Scientific American‚Äôs Claire Cameron. ‚ÄúThat opens the field considerably to how cheetahs are sourced and the implications of introducing diversity into the gene pool.‚Äù
Cheetahs (Acinonyx jubatus) currently reside in less than 10 percent of their historic range across Africa and Asia. Researchers recognize five living subspecies of the wild cat. Asiatic cheetahs (A. j. venaticus) are thought to have gone extinct in the Arabian Peninsula in the 1970s.
Did you know? Built for speed
Cheetahs are famous for being the fastest land mammal. They can accelerate from 0 miles per hour to 45 miles per hour in merely 2.5 seconds, and their speed maxes out at around 70 miles per hour.
In 2022 and 2023, researchers descended into underground caves in northern Saudi Arabia to survey wildlife. Surprisingly, a few of them held troves of bygone cheetahs: skeletal remains from 54 cats and 7 mummified animals.
‚ÄúThe fact that they went into over one hundred caves and were able to find mummies‚Äîthat‚Äôs highly unusual outside of [things like] permafrost,‚Äù which has turned up many mummified Ice Age animals, Liz Kierepka, a wildlife geneticist at North Carolina State University who was not involved in the study, tells Science News‚Äô Jake Buehler.
No evidence suggests that modern cheetahs use caves for shelter or food storage, so the ancient cats may have fallen or climbed in and become trapped, the researchers write in the paper. The dry, dark caves then preserved their bodies for up to several millennia.
Radiocarbon dating of the seven mummified cheetahs revealed that the youngest animal lived about 127 years ago, while the oldest lived more than 4,200 years ago. Moreover, the researchers analyzed the complete sets of genetic instructions, or genomes, from three of the mummies‚Äîthe youngest, the oldest and one in the middle. Only the most recent cat was closely related to the Asiatic cheetah, the team found. The more ancient ones were genetically more similar to the Northwest African cheetah (A. j. hecki).
Because of this, the researchers suggest that both subspecies could be used to help bring cheetahs back to Saudi Arabia. The country has been pursuing an ambitious plan to rewild the land, reintroducing animals including the ostrich, Arabian oryx and Persian onager.
Moreover, the discovery adds to researchers‚Äô knowledge of the Asiatic cheetah.
‚ÄúThis is really exciting work,‚Äù says Molly Cassatt-Johnstone, a paleogenomicist at the University of California, Santa Cruz who was not involved in the paper, to National Geographic‚Äôs Annie Roth. ‚ÄúRecovering these mummified specimens and generating paleogenomic data from them is a huge contribution to our understanding of a critically endangered subspecies.‚Äù

These Hungry Starfish Are Spiraling Out of Control in Australia. Now Scientists Say They Have a New Plan to Fight Back
Synthetic pheromones may be a promising tool in attracting and culling troublesome crown-of-thorns starfish, which rapidly eat large amounts of coral on the Great Barrier Reef
For decades, crown-of-thorns starfish (COTS) have been rampaging out of control. These pizza-size sea stars are native to the Indo-Pacific region, including Australia‚Äôs Great Barrier Reef, but their insatiable appetite for coral, dwindling roster of predators and high reproductive capacity mean that a small population can quickly multiply to plague proportions, devastating struggling reefs.
Across the Indo-Pacific, conservationists at war with COTS have developed a range of special weapons and tactics to take them on. But these stubborn starfish are extremely hard to kill. Not only are they covered in venomous spines that make them difficult for divers to handle; they also release toxic slime when threatened, which can harm surrounding marine life. COTS are resilient, too. As with other sea stars, an entirely new individual can grow into existence from what was once a severed limb that retains some of the central body. And thus, just as Mickey Mouse‚Äôs desperate act of chopping up a magical broomstick gives rise to an army of clones in Disney‚Äôs Fantasia, slicing and dicing crown-of-thorns starfish can do more harm than good.
To date, scientists have come up with several ways to safely slay these sea stars and protect coral ecosystems, but they all involve finding and killing the invertebrates one by one, which is time-consuming, costly and not particularly effective when an outbreak can number in the millions of individuals. But an international team of researchers has recently developed a new way to help control COTS‚Äîone that co-opts the animals‚Äô own communication systems to lure them to their deaths.
The trick, according to research published last year by scientists in Australia and Japan, is to release synthetic starfish pheromones into the water. In laboratory trials, at least, the scientists found that pheromones can lure large numbers of COTS to one place so they can be bumped off en masse. This new method, the researchers say, has the potential to make culling crown-of-thorns sea stars vastly more efficient and cost-effective.
On a healthy coral reef, COTS help maintain the balance of the ecosystem, says Scott Cummins, a molecular biologist at Australia‚Äôs University of the Sunshine Coast and a co-author of the study. But when people destabilize the environment by overfishing the starfish‚Äôs predators, or when pollution and nutrient runoff trigger an algal bloom, the species can quickly become an existential threat.
Quick fact: A new starfish outbreak on the Great Barrier Reef
Australia‚Äôs Great Barrier Reef has faced four destructive outbreaks of crown-of-thorns starfish, which have appeared approximately every 15 years since the 1960s. Recent research and news reports suggest that a fifth outbreak is now emerging in the reef‚Äôs northern region.
A single female COTS can release more than 200 million eggs per year. What‚Äôs worse, an adult COTS consumes enough coral every year to strip bare a roughly 110-square-foot chunk of coral reef, which is about the size of a small bedroom. That may not seem like much, but with potentially millions of sea stars at work, a healthy reef can be reduced to rubble in a matter of weeks. This is what almost happened near the Japanese island of Okinawa roughly 40 years ago, when divers were forced to remove more than 1.5 million starfish by hand to keep the reef from being overtaken.
Since then, scientists have been looking for better ways to cull COTS. Recent advances have included killing the invertebrates by injecting them with vinegar or lime juice, which slowly turns them to mush and helps conservationists avoid handling the spiny starfish. Scientists have even developed an autonomous underwater vehicle, known as the RangerBot, designed to dole out death. But these approaches still require conservationists to track the starfish down one by one.
Cummins‚Äô new strategy, of using the starfish‚Äôs own pheromones to draw them in close, came from years of studying sea slugs‚Äîinvertebrates with poor vision that primarily communicate through chemical signals. The work led Cummins to discover that many other marine species, including COTS, also release small proteins known as peptides into the water to communicate, using these signals to meet up and coordinate activities like mating. ‚ÄúIf you can understand how an animal communicates, you might be able to manipulate their behavior,‚Äù Cummins says.
Having identified the specific peptides that cause the sea stars to swarm, Cummins and his colleagues created a synthetic version. Laboratory trials with their mixture of peptides‚Äîdubbed ‚ÄúAcanthaster attractins‚Äù for crown-of-thorns‚Äô scientific genus, Acanthaster‚Äîcaused adult sea stars to beeline toward the pheromones. And not only are Cummins‚Äô synthetic pheromones effective; they‚Äôre also entirely nontoxic.
This new approach, says Maria Byrne, a marine biologist at Australia‚Äôs University of Sydney who was not involved with the study, ‚Äúholds great promise‚Äù for efforts to control COTS. ‚ÄúHowever,‚Äù she adds, because coral reefs are chemically complicated places, with lots of species releasing all sorts of scents and signals, a real coral reef, unlike a lab, is already rich with ‚Äúchemicals that the crown-of-thorns starfish may respond to. So it will be important to conduct field trials to see how the chemical works in nature.‚Äù
Cummins hopes to begin field trials along the Great Barrier Reef soon. Australians ‚Äúhave been fighting against [COTS] for 50 years,‚Äù he says. Though more research is needed before field trials can begin, Cummins is looking forward to what comes next. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs an exciting time.‚Äù

articles.content:
This Magnificent Mural by Leonardo da Vinci Will Go on Display for a Brief Window During the Winter Olympics in Milan
Guided tours will take visitors onto scaffolding to view the rare artwork inside Sforza Castle, which is currently undergoing restorations
For a precious five-week period this February and March, coinciding with the Milano Cortina Olympics, Italian officials are allowing visitors to access a mural painted by Leonardo da Vinci and his workshop that‚Äôs typically off-limits.
The late 15th-century piece extends across the ceiling and walls of the Sala delle Asse in Sforza Castle, an elite residence that was later converted into a museum campus. From February 7 to March 14, guided tours will give the public the chance to climb a 20-foot scaffold and view the work ‚Äúfrom just a few centimeters away,‚Äù according to a Milan municipality statement.
Visitors will have 30 minutes inside the room, and they must wear safety helmets.
‚ÄúThe [Milan] City Council reaffirms its commitment to promoting an increasingly in-depth and accessible understanding of the city‚Äôs cultural heritage, for the benefit of Milanese residents and the many visitors who will flock to the city for the Winter Olympics,‚Äù Tommaso Sacchi, the city‚Äôs culture counselor, says in the statement.
Leonardo began work on the mural in 1498, painting intertwined vines, branches, roots and rocks. But the full piece was never completed. The artists were forced to abandon the mural just a year later, when Milan was seized during a French invasion. Leonardo fled the city.
The mural was gradually forgotten in the centuries that followed, as the French covered it with plaster. It didn‚Äôt resurface again until the late-19th and early-20th centuries, when historians and archaeologists began to peel back the room‚Äôs plaster layers. Early restorers filled in places where its color had faded, a practice that has changed how some view the work.
‚ÄúAs a result, Leonardo scholars no longer recognized them as a true Leonardo, but rather as a repainted Leonardo, somewhat a fake, to use a popular term,‚Äù Luca Tosi, heritage curator at Sforza Castle, tells the Associated Press‚Äô Niccol√≤ Lupone.
Starting in February, visitors will be able to watch conservators as they use Japanese rice paper and demineralized water to remove salt that seeped into the ceiling and walls over the centuries. The practice is a way to carefully clean the artwork without disturbing Leonardo‚Äôs tempera paint, Artnet‚Äôs Margaret Carrigan reports.
In addition to the Sala delle Asse, the castle‚Äôs museums will be open as usual, with two new Leonardo-themed exhibitions. Inside the nearby Panoramic Rooms, a multimedia installation will share the story of Leonardo‚Äôs role within the Sforza court.
Quick fact: Sforza Castle‚Äôs subterranean structures
In early 2025, researchers announced that they‚Äôd identified passageways under the castle that match those found in Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs drawings.
Meanwhile, room XXI of the Pinacoteca del Castello Sforzesco art gallery will open with a redesigned exhibition about the ‚ÄúLeonardeschi‚Äù‚Äîartists who trained in Leonardo‚Äôs workshop or were otherwise meaningfully influenced by his style. Archaeologists Unearthed a 430,000-Year-Old Stick. After Careful Analysis, They Say It Could Be the Oldest Wooden Tool Ever Discovered
Found in southern Greece, the stick was one of two wooden artifacts that appear to have been shaped intentionally, according to a new study
Researchers working along a lake shore in southern Greece have identified the oldest known handheld wooden tools ever found. The rare artifacts date to around 430,000 years ago.
The items were likely used by early Neanderthals or a species known as Homo heidelbergensis during the Middle Pleistocene, an era of human evolution ‚Äúcharacterized by increasing behavioral complexity and the first unambiguous evidence of plant-based technologies,‚Äù as the researchers write in the journal PNAS, where their discovery was published this week.
‚ÄúWe found marks from chopping and carving on both objects, clear signs that humans had shaped them,‚Äù lead author Annemieke Milks, an archaeologist at the University of Reading in England, tells the New York Times‚Äô Franz Lidz.
The discoveries were made at a dig site called Marathousa 1, a mine in Greece‚Äôs Megalopolis basin. The area likely offered protection during a period of extreme weather nearly half a million years ago. The site‚Äôs loose sediments and wet environment helped bury and preserve the 144 pieces of wood that archaeologists excavated at the site between 2013 and 2019.
Quick fact: Tools fashioned from elephant bone
News of the wooden artifacts‚Äô discovery comes several days after researchers in England published a study analyzing a 480,000-year-old tool made from elephant bone‚Äîlikely the oldest tool of its kind found in Europe.
Among these items, two stood out as particularly intriguing when viewed under a microscope. Their markings, wear and internal structure suggested that they‚Äôd been intentionally shaped.
One tool, a thin stick roughly 2.7 feet long and made from alder wood, was possibly used to help dig through mud for planting or harvesting food. However, nearby discoveries invite new questions. The artifact was unearthed alongside elephant bones, and researchers wonder if it could have been used to process the animal‚Äôs carcass.
‚ÄúI‚Äôve never tried to cut up an elephant carcass, so I don‚Äôt know,‚Äù co-author Katerina Harvati, a paleoanthropologist at the University of T√ºbingen in Germany, tells the Times. ‚ÄúI assume it‚Äôs not so easy, but I mean, I guess it‚Äôs possible.‚Äù
The second artifact‚Äôs purpose has been more difficult to discern. Made from a willow or poplar tree, the piece measures just a few inches long. It appears to have been carefully stripped of bark for some intentional purpose. One possibility is that it was used to retouch stone tools, but ‚Äúwe don‚Äôt really know what it was for,‚Äù Harvati tells New Scientist‚Äôs Michael Marshall.
Dirk Leder, an archaeologist at the Lower Saxony State Office for Cultural Heritage in Germany who wasn‚Äôt involved in the study, is impressed by the larger artifact, but he isn‚Äôt sold on the smaller object‚Äôs characterization as a tool. ‚ÄúMy first question would be, is this actually a complete item, or is it rather a fragment of something?‚Äù Leder says to New Scientist.
The discoveries are thought to be the world‚Äôs oldest known wooden tools, though they‚Äôre not the oldest known wooden artifacts. In 2019, archaeologists in Zambia found 476,000-year-old interlocking logs that may have once been part of a wooden structure.
Artifacts made from organic materials rarely survive this long outside arid locations like Egypt, Maeve McHugh, a classical archaeologist at England‚Äôs University of Birmingham who wasn‚Äôt involved in the research, tells NBC News‚Äô Yuliya Talmazan. She adds that the discovery of such a rare wooden artifact that provides insights into early human ancestors‚Äô lives is ‚Äúvery interesting and important.‚Äù
There is still more to learn regarding the function of the newly discovered wooden items. For some researchers, these unanswered questions are enough to keep expectations in check.
‚ÄúIt‚Äôs difficult to get excited about these because they don‚Äôt strike you immediately as wooden tools,‚Äù Jarod Hutson, an archaeologist with the Smithsonian‚Äôs National Museum of Natural History who was not involved in the study, tells the Associated Press‚Äô Adithi Ramakrishnan. ‚ÄúAnd we don‚Äôt know what they were used for.‚Äù
